name: A1 : Sentences

questions.question: I'm off for two weeks at August.
options: ~I'm off for two weeks at August.
=I'm off for two weeks in August.
~I'm off for two weeks on August.
~I'm off for two weeks between August.
questions.examples:
My friend at work is from Japan.
The factory workers have been on strike since January.
Between you and me, I don't think he's a very good teacher.

Explanation:
The given examples look at the remaining three possibilities of using the prepositions ‘at’, ‘on’ and ‘between’. The preposition ‘at’ is used with a place or a location, which we see in the example statement “My friend at work is from Japan”. Here, ‘at’ signifies that the subject is located at ‘work’. The preposition ‘on’ is used to indicate a position, which as seen in the second example statement, refers to the position of “strike”. ‘Between’ is used when there are two separate points of reference mentioned, which, as we see in the third example statement, ‘you’ and ‘me’.

questions.question: The factory workers have been on strike since January.
options: =The factory workers have been on strike since January.
~The factory workers have been in strike since January.
~The factory workers have been about strike since January.
~The factory workers have been through strike since January.
questions.examples:
I'm off for two weeks in August.
We were talking about you.
We have to drive through the tunnel to get to my friend's place.

Explanation:
The preposition ‘in’ is used to indicate a position within something, as seen in the sentence “I’m off for two weeks in August.” Since ‘about’ is used to indicate around or nearby something or referring to a subject, we see this in “We were talking about you.” ‘Through’ is used when you have something with limits on top, bottom and the sides as indicated by “We have to drive through the tunnel to get to my friend’s place.”

questions.question: During our visit to Japan, we saw a lot of interesting places.
options: =During our visit to Japan, we saw a lot of interesting places.
~While our visit to Japan, we saw a lot of interesting places.
~Through our visit to Japan, we saw a lot of interesting places.
~When our visit to Japan, we saw a lot of interesting places.
questions.examples:
The phone rang while I was watching TV.
She rode through the forest on her horse.

Explanation:
‘While’ is used to talk about two things that are happening at the same time. The length of time is not important. Ex: The phone rang while I was watching TV. ‘Through’ is used as a preposition to indicate from one end or side of something/somebody to the other. Ex: She rode through the forest on her horse.

questions.question: Another way of saying 'old-fashioned' is 'beside the times'.
options: ~Another way of saying 'old-fashioned' is 'beside the times'.
=Another way of saying 'old-fashioned' is 'behind the times'.
~Another way of saying 'old-fashioned' is 'outside the times'.
~Another way of saying 'old-fashioned' is 'beforethe times'.
questions.examples:
Your accounting methods are behind the times.
Sarah is a bit behind the times. Her clothes are quite old-fashioned.
Our 90â€”year-old state senator is a bit behind the times.

Explanation:
Some other ways in which this idiom may be used in a sentence are as given. Here, the subject may vary, but the idea remains the same. The subject is described as being old – fashioned or not keeping up with current fashion, methods, or ideas.

questions.question: Spain is one of a largest European countries.
options: ~Spain is one of a largest European countries.
~Spain is one of an largest European countries.
~Spain is one of largest European countries.
=Spain is one of the largest European countries.
questions.examples:
This lake has the clearest water.
This bowl is the biggest one.
This exam is the easiest.

Explanation:
As we see in each of the examples given here, the verb on which the comparison is being made takes on ‘the’ as an article before itself. Here, there is a comparison being made and the quality is of the highest degree.

questions.question: Let’s go to the Mexico.
options: ~Let’s go to the Mexico.
=Let’s go to Mexico.
~Let’s go to a Mexico.
~Let’s go to an Mexico.
questions.examples:
I'm from China.
I've climbed Mount Everest.
She speaks French.

Explanation:
As per the rules of using articles, names of countries do not require an article before them. Similarly, ‘Mount Everest’ is something that everyone knows, because there is only one Mount Everest in the entire world. Therefore, it does not require an article.

questions.question: I got an lot of good presents for my birthday.
options: ~I got an lot of good presents for my birthday.
~I got the lot of good presents for my birthday.
=I got a lot of good presents for my birthday.
~I got lot of good presents for my birthday.
questions.examples:
Love can cause a lot of suffering.
With a lot of practice, using articles correctly will become second nature.

Explanation:
The phrase ‘lot of’ puts the entire set of articles into one subject. When the subject is an ‘uncount’ noun the article to be used before such a singular subject becomes ‘a’. So, we have the sentence “Love can cause a lot of suffering”.

questions.question: Do you have pen I could borrow?
options: ~Do you have pen I could borrow?
~Do you have the pen I could borrow?
~Do you have an pen I could borrow?
=Do you have a pen I could borrow?
questions.examples:
A man is walking down a road.
Seiko is a practicing Buddhist.

Explanation:
In these examples, the subject is a noun in the singular, third person form starting with a vowel sound. Hence, the article to be placed before “man” or “road” in Example 1 or before “practicing” in example 2 is “a”.

questions.question: Do you remember exact date when the war started?
options: ~Do you remember exact date when the war started?
=Do you remember the exact date when the war started?
~Do you remember an exact date when war started?
~Do you remember a exact date when the war started?
questions.examples:
There is a dog with the man.
Combine butter, sugar and eggs. Add flour to the mixture.
The Prime Minister will arrive tomorrow.

Explanation:
In each of the sentences in the examples, the definite article “the” has been placed before a noun which qualifies one of these two conditions. One, the noun / pronoun refers to something or someone mentioned earlier on in the conversation. So, the listener knows exactly who / what is being referred to in the sentence. Two, the noun is a universally known subject, in which case, the listener is again absolutely clear on who / what is being referred to.

questions.question: I can spell as well as the most students.
options: ~I can spell as well as the most students.
~I can spell as well as anmost students.
~I can spell as well as a most students.
=I can spell as well as most students.
questions.examples:
In Mumbai, you can always get into town late at night and home again by bus or taxi.

Explanation:
In the given example, there is no requirement of an article preceding any of the nouns in the sentence as there is no aspect of comparison or reference.

questions.question: I have an wonderful idea!
options: ~I have an wonderful idea!
=I have a wonderful idea!
~I have the wonderful idea!
~I have wonderful idea!
questions.examples:
That was a lovely dinner!
The koala is a marsupial.

Explanation:
The article in a sentence where an adjective precedes a noun would follow the path of the adjective and not the noun. Since the subject in each of the given set of sentences is a singular noun, with an adjective beginning with a consonant sound, the article to be used here becomes ‘a’.

questions.question: Someone call an doctor!
options: ~Someone call an doctor!
=Someone call the doctor!
~Someone call doctor!
~Someone call doctors!
questions.examples:
Somebody call a policeman!
My daughter really wants a dog for Christmas.

Explanation:
"Somebody call a policeman!" This refers to any policeman. We don't need a specific policeman; we need any policeman who is available. "My daughter really wants a dog for Christmas." This refers to any dog. We don't know which dog because we haven't found the dog yet. Hence, we place the article “a” before the noun in both the sentences.

questions.question: Is this the bad time? Should I call you later?
options: ~Is this the bad time? Should I call you later?
~Is this bad time? Should I call you later?
~Is this one bad time? Should I call you later?
=Is this a bad time? Should I call you later?
questions.examples:
Please give me a bottle of water.
We need a light in this room.

Explanation:
In both these example sentences, while the nouns are both uncount nouns – “water” and “light”, we are making them countable nouns by describing them / limiting them with “bottle” and “light” (meaning a lamp or a source of light). Since the nouns are now countable, the article “a” is placed before them.

questions.question: I know the shortcut to reach the theatre on time.
options: ~I know the shortcut to reach the theatre on time.
~I know shortcut to reach the theatre on time.
~I know an shortcut to reach the theatre on time.
=I know a shortcut to reach the theatre on time.
questions.examples:
My daughter really wants a dog for Christmas.
When I was at the zoo, I saw an elephant!

Explanation:
"My daughter really wants a dog for Christmas." This refers to any dog. We don't know which dog because we haven't found the dog yet. Hence, we place the article “a” before the noun in both the sentences. “When I was at the zoo, I saw an elephant!” Here, we're talking about a specific noun. Probably, there is only one elephant at the zoo.

questions.question: The President of the USA lives in White House.
options: ~The President of the USA lives in White House.
=The President of the USA lives in the White House.
~The President of the USA lives in a White House.
~The President of USA lives in anWhite House.
questions.examples:
One day I would like to fly to the moon and visit the nearest planets.
The captain checked the position of the Northern Star to determine the location of his ship.
Explanation:
The definite article is used before a noun which refers to a specific, unique object. The noun is a universally known subject, in which case, the listener is again absolutely clear on who / what is being referred to. This rule is now exemplified in these two example sentences where we refer to the moon, the nearest planets, the Northern Star etc.

questions.question: I spoke with the specialist I told you about.
options: =I spoke with the specialist I told you about.
~I spoke with a specialist I told you about.
~I spoke with anspecialist I told you about.
~I spoke with specialist I told you about.
questions.examples:
A woman who fell 10 metres from High Peak was lifted to safety by a helicopter. The woman fell while climbing.
He is the doctor I came to see.

Explanation:
In each of the sentences in the examples, the definite article “the” has been placed before a noun refers to something or someone mentioned earlier on in the conversation. So, the listener knows exactly who / what is being referred to in the sentence.

questions.question: Mount Everest is tallest mountain.
options: ~Mount Everest is tallest mountain.
~Mount Everest is a tallest mountain.
=Mount Everest is the tallest mountain.
~Mount Everest is one tallest mountain.
questions.examples:
He is the tallest boy in the class.
It is the oldest building in the town
Explanation:
Superlative Form is used when three or more nouns are being compared and we need to show that one or more of the nouns possess the adjective or characteristic to the highest amount possible. We usually add ‘the’ before the superlative form – biggest, sweetest, cleanest, etc. This rule is exemplified in the two examples.

questions.question: Several friends played baseball together.
options: =Several friends played baseball together.
~Several friends will played baseball together.
~Several friends plays baseball together.
~Several friends to play baseball together.
questions.examples:
She washed her car.
Last year, I traveled to Japan.
Explanation:
The two example sentences are in the Simple Past Tense. Hence, the verbs in both the sentences “to wash” and “to travel” both take on the tense form to fit in.

questions.question: She cross the street.
options: ~She cross the street.
=She crossed the street.
~She havecrossed the street.
~She crossing the street.
questions.examples:
I saw a movie yesterday.
I didn't see a play yesterday.
Explanation:
The two example sentences are in the Simple Past Tense. Hence, the verbs in both the sentences “to see” and “to not see” both take on the tense form to fit in.

questions.question: The workers hasa new schedule.
options: ~The workers hasa new schedule.
~The workers given a new schedule.
~The workers had been a new schedule.
=The workers have a new schedule.
questions.examples:
I saw a movie yesterday.
I didn't see a play yesterday.
Explanation:
The two example sentences are in the Simple Past Tense. Hence, the verbs in both the sentences “to see” and “to not see” both take on the tense form to fit in.

questions.question: Ambika meet Sonia at the corner.
options: ~Ambika meet Sonia at the corner.
=Ambika met Sonia at the corner.
~Ambikato meet Sonia at the corner.
~Ambikameeted Sonia at the corner.
questions.examples:
I saw a movie yesterday.
I didn't see a play yesterday.

Explanation:
The two example sentences are in the Simple Past Tense. Hence, the verbs in both the sentences “to see” and “to not see” both take on the tense form to fit in.

questions.question: Hari jog in the morning.
options: ~Hari jog in the morning.
~Hari joggerin the morning.
=Hari will jog in the morning.
~Hari jogging in the morning.
questions.examples:
You will help him later.
You are going to meet Jane tonight.

Explanation:
"Will" often suggests that a speaker will do something voluntarily. A voluntary action is one the speaker offers to do for someone else. "Be going to" expresses that something is a plan. It expresses the idea that a person intends to do something in the future. It does not matter whether the plan is realistic or not. Both these rules are exemplified in the examples given.

questions.question: Every morning Ambika get up and feeds the cat.
options: ~Every morning Ambika gets up and feeds the cat.
~Every morning Ambika get up and feed the cat.
=Every morning Ambika gets up and feeds the cat.
~Every morning Ambika gets up and feed the cat.
questions.examples:
He drinks tea at breakfast.
She only eats fish.
They watch television regularly.
Explanation:
The Simple Present is used to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens. This is the idea which is exemplified in the given sentences.

questions.question: Bala hopes that Dinesh will win the race.
options: =Bala hopes that Dinesh will win the race.
~Bala hope that Dinesh wins the race.
~Bala will hoping that Dinesh will win the race.
~Bala hoped that Dinesh won the race.
questions.examples:
The restaurant opens at 19.30 tonight.
Next Thursday at 14.00 there is an English exam.
The plane leaves in ten minutes.

Explanation:
In the given set of example sentences, the simple present is used to make statements about events at a time later than now, when the statements are based on present facts, and when these facts are something fixed like a time-table, schedule, calendar.

questions.question: We playing a computer game at the moment.
options: ~We playing a computer game at the moment.
~We will playing a computer game at the moment.
=We are playing a computer game at the moment.
~We played a computer game at the moment.
questions.examples:
You are learning English now.
You are not swimming now.

Explanation:
In the given set of sentences, we use the Present Continuous to express the idea that something is happening now, at this very moment. It can also be used to show that something is not happening now.

questions.question: Nandini often forgottenher homework.
options: ~Nandini often forgottenher homework.
~Nandini often forget her homework.
=Nandini often forgets her homework.
~Nandini often forgetful her homework.
questions.examples:
He drinks tea at breakfast.
She only eats fish.
They watch television regularly.

Explanation:
In the given set of example sentences, the simple present is used to make statements about events at a time later than now, when the statements are based on present facts, and when these facts are something fixed like a time-table, schedule, calendar.

questions.question: I have preparing lunch.
options: ~I have preparing lunch.
=I am preparing lunch.
~I did preparing lunch.
~I am prepared lunch.
questions.examples:
You are learning English now.
You are not swimming now.

Explanation:
In the given set of sentences, we use the Present Continuous to express the idea that something is happening now, at this very moment. It can also be used to show that something is not happening now.

questions.question: Janani will already typed five pages when her computer crashed.
options: ~Janani will already typed five pages when her computer crashed.
~Janani already typed five pages when her computer crashed.
~Janani could already typed five pages when her computer crashed.
=Janani had already typed five pages when her computer crashed.
questions.examples:
Even when he was young, Dali was fascinated by and disturbed about how ants ate animal carcasses.
When you're in London, write an e-mail to me.

Explanation:
The given sentences are a mix of Tenses, where the subject is in one time frame and the action in another. In the sentence “Even when he was young, Dali was fascinated by and disturbed about how ants ate animal carcasses”, knowing, as we do, that the artist is no longer alive and that the sentiment refers specifically to him, the point is no longer valid, so past tense here is proper. Similarly, in the second sentence, “When you're in London, write an e-mail to me” it refers to a point in the future.

questions.question: I correcting it by the end of the day.
options: ~I correcting it by the end of the day.
~I may corrected it by the end of the day.
~I correct it by the end of the day.
=I will correct it by the end of the day.
questions.examples:
He'll carry your bag for you.
I will see the movie this weekend.

Explanation:
"Will" often suggests that a speaker will do something voluntarily. A voluntary action is one the speaker offers to do for someone else. This rule is exemplified in the examples given.

questions.question: They leaving work at the end of the hour.
options: ~They leaving work at the end of the hour.
~They leaves work at the end of the hour.
=They leave work at the end of the hour.
~They will left work at the end of the hour.
questions.examples:
He'll carry your bag for you.
I will see the movie this weekend.
Explanation:
"Will" often suggests that a speaker will do something voluntarily. A voluntary action is one the speaker offers to do for someone else. This rule is exemplified in the examples given.

questions.question: Have you received any informations?
options: =Have you received any information?
~Had you received any informations?
~Have they received any informations?
~Had you received any information?
questions.examples:
The price of freedom is constant vigilance.
Her writing shows maturity and intelligence.

Explanation:
Abstract nouns are uncountable. Some examples of such nouns are “freedom”, “maturity”, “intelligence” etc. and these are being used in the given set of sentences.

questions.question: She sings good
options: =She sings well.
~She sings best
~She sings bad
~She sings good
questions.examples:
She is a good tennis player.
She did extremely well on the exam.

Explanation:
In the given sentences, the concept is of comparison. However, the subject ‘she’ is not being compared to some other individual. Here, ‘good’ is an adjective. And what we need is an adverb which would qualify the verb ‘to do’.

questions.question: Everybody came accept Ram
options: ~Everybody have come except Ram
=Everybody came except Ram
~Everybody had come accept Ram
~Everybody has come accept Ram
questions.examples:
accept his opinion; accept an award
There was nothing left except bread.

Explanation:
To accept is to receive, and except is to exclude, usually. The given set of sentences provides the context for the usage of these words.

questions.question: It is past your bedtime.
options: ~It has passed your bedtime.
=It is past your bedtime
~You bedtime is passed
~It also past your bedtime
questions.examples:
Forget the past.
The days for mourning are now past.

Explanation:
The word past locates something in time, and sometimes in space. It can be used as an adjective, noun, or adverb. The first definition for past as an adjective is “Gone by in time; elapsed; done with; over.”

questions.question: He felled off the ladder and broke his leg
options: ~He felled from the ladder and broke his leg
~He felt from ladder and broke his leg
=He fell off the ladder and broke his leg
~He felled off the ladder and broke his leg
questions.examples:
fall off a bicycle, off the wagon or off the radar
fall off or from the roof or the top of a mountain
Explanation:
In general "fall off" implies a sense of movement or detachment from something while "fall from" is related to the location (physical or not - eg: grace). This difference is put in context with the given example sentences.

questions.question: She told to me about it.
options: =She told me about it.
~She telled me about it
~She spoke me about it
~She told to me about it
questions.examples:
Let me tell you a story.
Let me give you some money.
Explanation:
The examples show the usage of the verb ‘to tell’ and the preposition which follows the verb. ‘Tell’ is a verb which does not require a preposition to follow it, it indicates the person that will be spoken to. Similarly, the second sentence too does not need a preposition after the verb “to give”.

questions.question: The train is now approaching at the CST.
options: =The train is now approaching the CST.
~The train is now approaching at the CST.
~The train is now approaching to the CST.
~The train is now approaching on the CST.
questions.examples:
I'm approaching you for a reason.
I'm approaching you to get some results.

Explanation:
The verb ‘to approach’ does not require a preposition to follow it and this is shown in the example sentences stated.

questions.question: He excepted the award with great pleasure.
options: =He accepted the award with great pleasure.
~He accept award with great pleasure
~He excepted the ward with great pleasure.
~He except the award with great pleasure
questions.examples:
Do you accept dogs in your hotel?
The officer accepts your point and has decided to let you off with a caution.

Explanation:
To accept is to receive, and except is to exclude, usually. The given set of sentences provides the context for the usage of these words.

questions.question: If we both put our cards on the table it would be easier for us to come to an agreement.
options: =If we both put our cards on the table it would be easier for us to come to an agreement.
~If we both put our wallets on the table it would be easier for us to come to an agreement.
~If we both put our plans on the table it would be easier for us to come to an agreement.
~If we both put our thoughts on the table it would be easier for us to come to an agreement.
questions.examples:
I could only put my cards on the table and say I don't know what happened to this child.
She thought it was time to put her cards on the table and tell him that she had no intention of marrying him.

Explanation:
In the given set of sentences, the difference is made by the usage of the idiom ‘to put / lay your / our / cards on the table’. The meaning of this is “to be honest about your / our feelings and intentions” or “to truthfully explain what you know or think; to be very candid about one's position on some issue”.

questions.question: I spent a quiet afternoon at home reading to myself.
options: ~I spent an quiet afternoon at home reading to myself.
~I spent a quiet afternoon at home reading to herself.
~I spent a quiet afternoon at home reading to himself.
=I spent a quiet afternoon at home reading to myself.
questions.examples:
I want to dress myself today.
I got some ice cream for Grace and myself.

Explanation:
The pronoun “myself” should only be used when you are performing the action on yourself. No one else can do anything to yourself. This is seen in the two examples.

questions.question: Tomorrow we will be going to Tulasis party.
options: ~Tomorrow we will be going to Tulasis party.
~Tomorrow we will be going, to Tulasi’s party.
=Tomorrow, we will be going to Tulasi’s party.
~Tomorrow we will be going to Tulasi’s party.
questions.examples:
In similar usage, we can also see the examples given below for the placement of the comma.
Why, I can't believe this!
No, you can't have a dollar.

For a similar use of the apostrophe, have a look at the examples given below:
a woman's hat
the boss's wife
Mrs. Chang's house

Explanation:
The given examples show the usage and placement of the comma and the apostrophe.

questions.question: I am going to buy three apple.
options: ~I am going to buy three apple.
~I going to buy three apples.
~I go to buy three apples.
=I am going to buy three apples.
questions.examples:
A similar example in the usage of the Simple Future Tense can be seen in the sentence given below:
I am leaving later today.
He is going to faint.

Explanation:
A similar example in the usage of the Simple Future Tense can be seen in the sentences.

questions.question: In five minutes I will had been working for ten hours.
options: ~In five minutes I will had been working for ten hours.
=In five minutes, I will have been working for ten hours.
~In five minutes I will be working for ten hours.
~In five minutes, I had been working for ten hours.
questions.examples:
Some more examples which use the “will have been” + present form of the verb are:
Will you have been waiting for more than two hours when her plane finally arrives?
They will have been talking for over an hour by the time Thomas arrives.

Explanation:
"Will" often suggests that a speaker will do something voluntarily. A voluntary action is one the speaker offers to do for someone else. This rule is exemplified in the examples given.

questions.question: I will like more tea she said to the server.
options: ~I will like more tea she said to the server.
~“I will like more tea,” she said to the server.
=“I would like more tea,” she said to the server.
~“I like more tea,” she said to the server.
questions.examples:
Some other examples in similar form are:
When I was young I would do my homework every evening.
In the summer we would always go camping.

Explanation:
“Would” can be used to talk about actions that repeated in the past. It is used in the same context as “used to”. The usage of “would” in such a context can be seen in the examples given here.

questions.question: If he try hard enuf, Bill can become an actor some day.
options: ~If he try hard enuf, Bill can become an actor some day.
=If he tries hard enough, Bill could become an actor some day.
~If he tries hard enough, Bill can become an actor some day.
~If he try hard enough, Bill can become an actor some day.
questions.examples:
Some more examples which are similar are:
If we don’t hurry we could be late.
If you are not careful, you could lose your way in the dark.

Explanation:
We use could to show that something is possible in the future, but not certain or as a past tense of can, which can be seen in the examples given here.

questions.question: Today is Monday May four 2015.
options: ~Today is Monday May four 2015.
~Today is Monday May fourth 2015.
~Today is Monday, May fourth 2015.
=Today is Monday, May fourth, 2015.
questions.examples:
Some similar examples of this rule can be seen in the sentences given below:
The store closed its doors for good on Wednesday, October 15, 1958.
The meeting scheduled for July 10, 2011, was cancelled due to a hurricane watch.

Explanation:
When writing a date, a comma is used to separate the day from the month, and the date from the year.

questions.question: I simply cannot wait to get there!
options: =I simply cannot wait to get there!
~I simply cannot wait to getting there!
~I cannot simply wait to get there!
~I cannot wait simply to get there!
questions.examples:
Some more examples which show us the order of Subject-verb-object (and other parts of speech) in a sentence can be seen here:
We always have to wait a long time for the bus.
He sometimes plays golf on Sundays.

Explanation:
Some more examples which show us the order of Subject-verb-object (and other parts of speech) in a sentence can be seen in the given sentences.

questions.question: Me and my friend are gonna go to the beach next weekend.
options: ~Me and my friend are gonna go to the beach next weekend.
=My friend and I are going to go to the beach next weekend.
~My friend and me are going to the beach next weekend.
~My friend are gonna to the beach next weekend.
questions.examples:
Some more examples showing the order of I / me in a sentence are given here:
Janaki and I walked down the road.
If you have a problem, please call Rishi or me.
She gave the ball to Janaki and me.

Explanation:
When using ‘I’ in a sentence along with other people, we usually put the other person before I or me. Also, the easiest way to see if you’re using the correct word – I or me, in these sentences is to remove the name of the other person and see what pronoun is left.

questions.question: What he got for Diwali? she asked.
options: ~What he got for Diwali? she asked.
~“What he get for Diwali?” she asked.
=“What did he get for Diwali?” she asked.
~“What he gets for Diwali?” she asked.
questions.examples:
Some more examples in the same form are:
Did he bring his friend?
Did itrain on Sunday?

Explanation:
In the past tense, the verbs ‘to bring’ and ‘to rain’ become “did he bring” and “did it rain”, respectively, in the past tense, question form.

questions.question: When are we going?
options: =When are we going?
~When we are going?
~When going are we?
~When we going?
questions.examples:
Some other examples of the SVO order in question sentences are:
When were you here?
Whoaskedyou?

Explanation:
The order of parts of speech in the English Language is Subject – Verb – Object in sentences. In a question sentence, we use Question word + to be before nouns, pronouns, places and this / that. This word order is exemplified in the given set of sentences.

questions.question: We going now?
options: ~We going now?
=Are we going now?
~We going are now?
~We are go now?
questions.examples:
Some other examples of the SVO order in such question sentences are:
Are the students reading some books?
Will the students read some books?


Explanation:
In yes / no question sentences, a "helping verb" such as be, have, will, can, should, etc., moves to the left of the subject which is put in context in the given examples.

questions.question: Anyone wanna play with me?
options: ~Anyone wanna play with me?
~Anyone does wanting to play with me?
=Does anyone want to play with me?
~Anyone does wants t play with me?
questions.examples:
Some more examples to illustrate this are:
Do the students study physics?
Didyouhavea partyin your flatyesterday?


Explanation:
When a simple statement that does not contain a helping verb is expressed as a YES-NO question, the helping verb do shows up to the left of the subject.

questions.question: I has not seen them yet.
options: ~I has not seen them yet.
~I not seen them yet.
=I have not seen them yet.
~I have not see them yet.
questions.examples:
Some more examples for the Present Perfect:
Have you met Judy yet?
I haven't visited the Tate Gallery yet
Has he arrived yet?
They haven't eaten yet


Explanation:
We CAN use the Present Perfect with unspecific expressions such as: ever, never, once, many times, several times, before, so far, already, yet, etc. This is seen in the given set of examples.

questions.question: Hell be comin soon so dont worry.
options: ~Hell be comin soon so dont worry.
~He’ll be comin soon so don’t worry.
~He’ll be coming soon so don’t worry.
=He’ll be coming soon, so don’t worry.
questions.examples:
He said, "Dan cried, 'Do not treat me that way.' "
I don't paint anymore. For a while I thought it was just a phase that I'd get over.Now, I don't even try.


Explanation:
As a courtesy, make sure there is visible space at the start or end of a quotation between adjacent single and double quotation marks. When quoted material runs more than one paragraph, start each new paragraph with opening quotation marks, but do not use closing quotation marks until the end of the passage. These punctuation rules are seen in action in the given sentences.

questions.question: He likes cats, but she don’t like cats.
options: ~He likes cats, but she don’t like cats.
~He likes cats, but she don’t likes cats.
=He likes cats, but she doesn’t like cats.
~He like cats, but she doesn’t like cats.
questions.examples:
She always forgets her purse, but he never forgets his wallet.
I play tennis, but she does not play tennis.


Explanation:
The Simple Present can indicate the speaker believes that a fact was true before, is true now, and will be true in the future. It is not important if the speaker is correct about the fact. It is also used to make generalizations about people or things.

questions.question: When I get home, I will make dinner.
options: =When I get home, I will make dinner.
~When I got home, I will make dinner.
~When I get home, I make dinner.
~When I got home, I make dinner.
questions.examples:
When I get my salary tomorrow, I will buy a new computer.
I will give you a pen tomorrow.


Explanation:
These sentences talk about something that is planned for in the future; the verbs take on the Future Continuous form.

questions.question: My friends house is big red and expensive.
options: ~My friends house is big red and expensive.
=My friend’s house is big, red, and expensive.
~My friend’s house is big red and expensive.
~My friends house is big, red, and expensive.
questions.examples:
He hit the ball, dropped the bat, and ran to first base.
My estate goes to my husband, son, daughter-in-law, and nephew.


Explanation:
Use a comma to separate the elements in a series (three or more things), including the last two. This rule for the placement of commas in a sentence is seen in action in the given sentences.

questions.question: The old car doesn’t need to be fixed.
options: ~The old car doesn’t need fixed.
=The old car doesn’t need to be fixed.
~The old car do need to be fixed.
~The old car doesn’t need to be fix.
questions.examples:
No, it doesn't have a problem.
She doesn’t have to cook till next week.


Explanation:
The verb "have" is irregular in positive, third-person forms. In these sentences, we use the auxiliary “do / does + not” before the appropriate tense form of the verb “to have”.

questions.question: “Jeevan,” she said, “Could you please be quiet?”
options: ~Jeevan she said, Could you please be quiet?
~“Jeevan,” she said, “Can you please go quiet?”
=“Jeevan,” she said, “Could you please be quiet?”
~Jeevan, she said, Could you please quiet?
questions.examples:
“He loved you,” she said.
“He loved you,” she said, “but you didn’t care.”


Explanation:
Punctuation serves to separate the spoken words from other parts of the sentence. Commas go inside the first set of quotation marks and after the dialogue tag (or action).

questions.question: We going to the super market later?
options: ~We going to the super market later?
~Are we go to the super market later?
~Are we going the super market later?
=Are we going to the super market later?
questions.examples:
Some other examples of the SVO order in such question sentences are:
Are the students reading some books?
Will the students read some books?


Explanation:
In yes / no question sentences, a "helping verb" such as be, have, will, can, should, etc., moves to the left of the subject which is put in context in the given examples.

questions.question: Spot my dog is the faster runner in the hole neighborhood.
options: ~Spot my dog is the faster runner in the hole neighborhood.
=Spot, my dog, is the fastest runner in the whole neighborhood.
~Spot, my dog, is the faster runner in the whole neighborhood.
~Spot my dog is the fastest runner in the whole neighborhood.
questions.examples:
The Founders Bridge, which spans the Connecticut River, is falling down.
Heublein, a Hartford, Connecticut-based company, is moving to another state.


Explanation:
The placement of commas within the sentence to separate the part of a sentence that can be removed without changing the essential meaning of that sentence. This is seen in the examples.

questions.question: Once the train arrives we will be on are way.
options: ~Once the train arrives we will be on our way.
~Once the train arrives we will be on are way.
=Once the train arrives, we will be on our way.
~Once the train arrives, we will be on are way.
questions.examples:
Plans are nothing; planning is everything.
We shape our buildings; thereafter they shape us.


Explanation:
“Are” is used as the verb whereas “our” is the possessive form of ‘we’. This difference indicated in the given sentences.

questions.question: Apollo 11 was the first manned mission to land on the moon.
options: =Apollo 11 was the first manned mission to land on the moon.
~Apollo 11 is the first manned mission to land on the moon.
~Apollo 11 be the first manned mission to land on the moon.
~Apollo 11 the first manned mission to land on the moon.
questions.examples:
Rosie was able to finish her degree by taking online courses.
Robert Frost was America's favourite poet.


Explanation:
The “To be” verb can be combined with other modal forms (along with the past participle of the main verb) to convey other kinds of information. The various kinds of information conveyed by modals are advisability, predictability, guessing, necessity, possibility, etc.

questions.question: The cashere gave me two thousand and sixteen hundred rupees sixty paise.
options: ~The cashere gave me two thousand and sixteen hundred rupees sixty paise.
~The cashier gave me two thousand and sixteen hundred rupees sixty paise.
=The cashier gave me two thousand sixteen hundred rupees and sixty paise.
~The cashere gave me two thousand and sixteen hundred rupees and sixty paise.
questions.examples:
He earned thirty-thousand euros last year.
The software upgrade costs ninety-nine pounds and ninety-nine pence.


Explanation:
One of the rules to write a monetary amount in words is ‘Do not use the word "and" after "hundred" or "thousand" -- unless the number of paise follows immediately after’. This is seen in the examples given.

questions.question: I no have time.
options: ~I no have time.
=I do not have time.
~I do have not time.
~I not have time.
questions.examples:
No, it doesn't have a problem.
She doesn’t have to cook till next week.


Explanation:
The verb "have" is irregular in positive, third-person forms. In these sentences, we use the auxiliary “do / does + not” before the appropriate tense form of the verb “to have”.

questions.question: Learning the Sanskrit isn’t easy.
options: ~Learning the Sanskrit isn’t easy.
~Learning Sanskrit isn’t the easy.
~The learning Sanskrit isn’t easy.
=Learning Sanskrit isn’t easy.
questions.examples:
Formal education in Britain begins when children reach the age of five.
He adores dancing.


Explanation:
The given sentences are generic in nature, they do not require an article anywhere in the sentence.

questions.question: His health is more better.
options: ~His health is more better.
~His health is most better.
~His health is betterer.
=His health is much better.
questions.examples:
Ah!That's much better. Now I can't hear those awful bells.
The book was much better than I expected.


Explanation:
“Better" is an adjective, a description word. It's the comparative form of "good." Good, better, best. It is called the comparative form because it compares things: we say something is "better than" something else. "Much" is an adverb and modifies an adjective. "Much better" is a meaningful expression because we can talk about "better" comparisons as a matter of degree--somewhat better, a little better, much better.

questions.question: Why you did not come?
options: ~Why you did not come?
~Why not you come?
=Why did you not come?
~Why not you did come?
questions.examples:
Sarah and Orlando discussed their plans for the weekend.
We will not discuss what happened at the meeting.


Explanation:
In questions, the word order subject-verbs-object is question word + auxiliary + subject + verb + object. This order is seen in the examples.

questions.question: Let us discuss about this matter.
options: ~Let us discuss about this matter.
=Let us discuss this matter.
~Let us discuss in this matter.
~Let us discuss for this matter.
questions.examples:
Sarah and Orlando discussed their plans for the weekend.
We will not discuss what happened at the meeting.


Explanation:
The verb “to discuss” is transitive and therefore does not require a preposition to follow it. 'Discuss' means 'talk about', so 'discuss about' becomes 'talk about about'.

questions.question: Generally, girls are talkative than boys.
options: ~Generally, girls are talkative than boys.
=Generally, girls are more talkative than boys.
~Generally, girls are most talkative than boys.
~Generally, girls are too talkative than boys.
questions.examples:
They have finished most of the rice.
Many people came to visit the fair.


Explanation:
The Adjectives of Quantity - These adjectives help to show the amount or the approximate amount of the noun or pronoun. These adjectives do not provide exact numbers; rather they tell us the amount of the noun in relative or whole terms.

questions.question: Arpita is looking gorgeous in this dress.
options: =Arpita is looking gorgeous in this dress.
~Arpita is looking gorgeousest in this dress.
~Arpita is looking gorgeouser in this dress.
~Arpita is looking more gorgeous in this dress.
questions.examples:
New Delhi is a large city with many historical monuments.
Sheila is a beautiful woman.


Explanation:
The Adjectives of Quality - These adjectives are used to describe the nature of a noun. They give an idea about the characteristics of the noun by answering the question ‘what kind’, such as Honest, Kind, Large, Bulky, Beautiful, Ugly etc.

questions.question: She has a very sour voice.
options: ~She has a very sour voice.
~She has a very bittervoice.
=She has a very sweet voice.
~She has a very salty voice.
questions.examples:
New Delhi is a large city with many historical monuments.
Sheila is a beautiful woman.


Explanation:
The Adjectives of Quality - These adjectives are used to describe the nature of a noun. They give an idea about the characteristics of the noun by answering the question ‘what kind’, such as Honest, Kind, Large, Bulky, Beautiful, Ugly etc.

questions.question: Diamond is the hard natural material.
options: ~Diamond is the hard natural material.
~Diamond is the hardernatural material.
=Diamond is the hardest natural material.
~Diamond is the hardynatural material.
questions.examples:
She has the biggest dog in the colony.
He is the sweetest boy in his class.
The cupboard is the cleanest thing in the house.


Explanation:
Superlative Form is used when three or more nouns are being compared and we need to show that one or more of the nouns possess the adjective or characteristic to the highest amount possible. We usually add ‘the’ before the superlative form – biggest, sweetest, cleanest, etc. This rule is exemplified in the given examples.

questions.question: This exercise is quite more simple.
options: ~This exercise is quite more simple.
~This exercise is quite most simple.
=This exercise is quite simple.
~This exercise is quite more very simple.
questions.examples:
He is cleverer than her.
He is more clever than studious.


Explanation:
There a few adjectives that can use both ‘-er and -est’ and ‘more’ and ‘most’ to form their comparative and superlative forms. The distinction between these is that ‘-er and -est’ are used when we are comparing the noun to another noun and ‘more’ and ‘most’ is used when we are comparing characteristics within the noun.

questions.question: Rohan is a trustworthier boy.
options: =Rohan is a trustworthy boy.
~Rohan is a trustworthier boy.
~Rohan is a trustworthest boy.
~Rohan is a trustworthiest boy.
questions.examples:
New Delhi is a large city with many historical monuments.
Sheila is a beautiful woman.


Explanation:
The Adjectives of Quality - These adjectives are used to describe the nature of a noun. They give an idea about the characteristics of the noun by answering the question ‘what kind’, such as Honest, Kind, Large, Bulky, Beautiful, Ugly etc.

questions.question: The entire staff of the hotel we stayed at was very friendlier.
options: =The entire staff of the hotel we stayed at was very friendly.
~The entire staff of the hotel we stayed at was very friendlier.
~The entire staff of the hotel we stayed at was very friendliest.
~The entire staff of the hotel we stayed at was very friend.
questions.examples:
New Delhi is a large city with many historical monuments.
Sheila is a beautiful woman.


Explanation:
“Better" is an adjective, a description word. It's the comparative form of "good." Good, better, best. It is called the comparative form because it compares things: we say something is "better than" something else. "Much" is an adverb and modifies an adjective. "Much better" is a meaningful expression because we can talk about "better" comparisons as a matter of degree--somewhat better, a little better, much better.

questions.question: You are getting gooder all the time!
options: ~You are getting gooder all the time!

questions.examples:

Explanation:
The Adjectives of Quality - These adjectives are used to describe the nature of a noun. They give an idea about the characteristics of the noun by answering the question ‘what kind’, such as Honest, Kind, Large, Bulky, Beautiful, Ugly etc.

questions.question: Cricket is an excitinger game.
options: =Cricket is an exciting game.
~Cricket is an excitinger game.
~Cricket is an excitingest game.
~Cricket is an excite game.
questions.examples:
New Delhi is a large city with many historical monuments.
Sheila is a beautiful woman.


Explanation:
The usage of the apostrophe gives the noun a possessive form i.e. adding an apostrophe after the name. This is seen in the given sentences.

questions.question: Annoying music escaped from Kinya’s ear buds.
options: =Annoying music escaped from Kinya’s ear buds.
~Annoying music escaped from Kinyas ear buds.
~Annoying music escaped from Kinyas’ ear buds.
~Annoying music escaped from Kinya ear buds.
questions.examples:
Nita's mother constantly stressed minding one's p's and q's.
The dragon's burnt tooth was black.


Explanation:
The Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens. It can also be something a person often forgets or usually does not do.

questions.question: The game start every day at 8 p.m.
options: ~The game start every day at 8 p.m.
=The game starts every day at 8 p.m.
~The game starting every day at 8 p.m.
~The game started every day at 8 p.m.
questions.examples:
John sleeps eight hours every night during the week.
It rains a lot in winter.


Explanation:
The Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens. It can also be something a person often forgets or usually does not do.

questions.question: Many children drink milk with their meals.
options: =Many children drink milk with their meals.
~Many children drinks milk with their meals.
~Many children drinking milk with their meals.
~Many children drank milk with their meals.
questions.examples:
John sleeps eight hours every night during the week.
It rains a lot in winter.


Explanation:
The Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens. It can also be something a person often forgets or usually does not do.

questions.question: Our cat generally sleepa lot during the day.
options: ~Our cat generally sleep a lot during the day.
~Our cat generally slept a lot during the day.
~Our cat generally sleeping a lot during the day.
=Our cat generally sleeps a lot during the day.
questions.examples:
John sleeps eight hours every night during the week.
It rains a lot in winter.


Explanation:
The Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens. It can also be something a person often forgets or usually does not do.

options: ~Jai write a letter to his mother once a week.

~Jai written a letter to his mother once a week.
~Jai writing a letter to his mother once a week.
questions.examples:

The Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens. It can also be something a person often forgets or usually does not do.

questions.question: Shagun and Ishita livein a big city in the centre of the country.
options: =Shagun and Ishita live in a big city in the centre of the country.
~Shagun and Ishita lives in a big city in the centre of the country.
~Shagun and Ishita living in a big city in the centre of the country.
~Shagun and Ishita will living in a big city in the centre of the country.
questions.examples:
John sleeps eight hours every night during the week.
It rains a lot in winter.


Explanation:
The Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens. It can also be something a person often forgets or usually does not do.

questions.question: Usually tourists not goto Egypt to play golf.
options: ~Usually tourists not go to Egypt to play golf.
=Usually tourists do not go to Egypt to play golf.
~Usually tourists not going to Egypt to play golf.
~Usually tourists not went to Egypt to play golf.
questions.examples:
John sleeps eight hours every night during the week.
It rains a lot in winter.


Explanation:
The Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens. It can also be something a person often forgets or usually does not do.

questions.question: Raju always take the bus to go to school.
options: ~Raju always take the bus to go to school.
=Raju always takes the bus to go to school.
~Raju always taking the bus to go to school.
~Raju always taken the bus to go to school.
questions.examples:
John sleeps eight hours every night during the week.
It rains a lot in winter.


Explanation:
The Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens. It can also be something a person often forgets or usually does not do.

questions.question: We all know that many children not like vegetables.
options: ~We all know that many children not like vegetables.
=We all know that many children do not like vegetables.
~We all know that many children not liking vegetables.
~We all know that many children liking vegetables.
questions.examples:
John sleeps eight hours every night during the week.
It rains a lot in winter.


Explanation:
The Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens. It can also be something a person often forgets or usually does not do.

questions.question: Anne think it's a good idea to do English exercises.
options: ~Anne think it's a good idea to do English exercises.
=Anne thinks it's a good idea to do English exercises.
~Anne thinking it's a good idea to do English exercises.
~Anne thank it's a good idea to do English exercises.
questions.examples:
John sleeps eight hours every night during the week.
It rains a lot in winter.


Explanation:
The Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens. It can also be something a person often forgets or usually does not do.

questions.question: If you want to be healthy, you must eat good food.
options: =If you want to be healthy, you must eat good food.
~If you want is healthy, you must eat good food.
~If you want to be healthy, you must eating good food.
~If you want to be healthy, you must ate good food.
questions.examples:
John sleeps eight hours every night during the week.
It rains a lot in winter.


Explanation:
The Simple Present to express the idea that an action is repeated or usual. The action can be a habit, a hobby, a daily event, a scheduled event or something that often happens. It can also be something a person often forgets or usually does not do.

questions.question: Oil, which is lighter than water, rises to the surface.
options: =Oil, which is lighter than water, rises to the surface.
~Oil which is lighter than water rises to the surface.
~Oil which is lighter than water, rises to the surface.
~Oil, which is lighter than water rises to the surface.
questions.examples:
That Tuesday, which happens to be my birthday, is the only day when I am available to meet.
I appreciate your hard work. In this case, however, you seem to have over-exerted yourself.
This restaurant has an exciting atmosphere. The food, on the other hand, is rather bland.


Explanation:
We use a pair of commas in the middle of a sentence to set off clauses, phrases, and words that are not essential to the meaning of the sentence. Use one comma before to indicate the beginning of the pause and one at the end to indicate the end of the pause.

questions.question: The closet contained worn clothes, old shoes, and dirty hats.
options: =The closet contained worn clothes, old shoes, and dirty hats.
~The closet contained worn clothes old shoes and dirty hats.
~The closet contained worn clothes old shoes, and dirty hats.
~The closet contained worn clothes, old shoes and dirty hats.
questions.examples:
My estate goes to my husband, son, daughter-in-law, and nephew.
We had coffee, cheese and crackers and grapes.


Explanation:
We use commas to separate words and word groups in a simple series of three or more items.

questions.question: August 15, 1947, will never be forgotten.
options: ~August 15 1947 will never be forgotten.
~August 15 1947, will never be forgotten.
=August 15, 1947, will never be forgotten.
~August 15, 1947 will never be forgotten.
questions.examples:
It was in the Sun's June 5, 2003, edition.
We will hold elections for class president on Monday, January 14, 2008.


Explanation:
We use commas to separate all geographical names, items in dates (except between the month and day) , addresses (except between the street number and name), and titles in names.

questions.question: The flight was safe enough wasn't it?
options: ~The flight was safe enough wasn't it?
~The flight was safe, enough, wasn't it?
~The flight, was safe enough, wasn't it?
=The flight was safe enough, wasn't it?
questions.examples:
He hit the ball well, but he ran too slowly to make a run.
She was still quite upset, although she had won the Oscar.


Explanation:
We use a comma near the end of a sentence to separate contrasted coordinate elements or to indicate a distinct pause or shift.

questions.question: Although he is considered a great writer, but his works are not widely read.
options: ~Although he is considered a great writer, but his works are not widely read.
=Although he is considered a great writer, his works are not widely read.
~Although he is considered a great writer, however his works are not widely read.
~Although he is considered a great writer, still his works are not widely read.
questions.examples:
Although the hurricane was headed our way last night, early this morning it turned north and missed Florida completely.
.Although Sarah spent most of her time in the garden or crocheting, Lisa soon discovered her favourite hobby was shopping, which she did at least once a week.


Explanation:
Whenever the sentence begins with the word ‘although’, which is a conjunction and therefore the sentence does not require a second conjunction word in the middle.

questions.question: You'll miss the train if you hurry up.
options: ~You'll miss the train if you hurry up.
~You'll miss the train as you hurry up.
~You'll miss the train until you hurry up.
=You'll miss the train unless you hurry up.
questions.examples:
I won't go unless it is free.
You can't enter unless you have a ticket.


Explanation:
Subordinating conjunctions join two clauses together, but in doing so, they make one clause dependent (or "subordinate") upon the other. This is seen in the usage of “unless” in the given sentences.

questions.question: It is neither hot and cold in winter in the south.
options: ~It is neither hot or cold in winter in the south.
=It is neither hot nor cold in winter in the south.
~It is neither hot but cold in winter in the south.
~It is neither hot and cold in winter in the south.
questions.examples:
Neither my mother nor my father went to university.
“I fear neither man nor beast!” Jay proclaimed as Frank stared at the python coiled on the branch over his head.


Explanation:
“Neither – nor” are used in a sentence in the negative sense when you want to say that two or more things are not true.

questions.question: The sun rise at 6:30 this morning and it was a beautiful sunrise.
options: ~The sun rise at 6:30 this morning and it was a beautiful sunrise.
=The sun rose at 6:30 this morning and it was a beautiful sunrise.
~The sun raises at 6:30 this morning and it was a beautiful sunrise.
~The sun risen at 6:30 this morning and it was a beautiful sunrise.
questions.examples:
I did not have any money because I had lost my wallet.
You had studied English before you moved to New York.


Explanation:
These sentences combine tenses to explain or project an idea. One part of the sentence in simple present and the other in simple past gives the continuation to the sequence of events, and this can be seen in the given set of examples.

questions.question: Take my advice, since you'll get into trouble.
options: ~Take my advice, but you'll get into trouble.
~Take my advice, since you'll get into trouble.
=Take my advice, or you'll get into trouble.
~Take my advice, so you'll get into trouble.
questions.examples:
You can study hard for this exam or you can fail.
Live free or die.


Explanation:
‘Or’ is a conjunction required to suggest that only one possibility can be realized, excluding one or the other as seen in the examples given here.

questions.question: You must be tired, or you haven't taken any break the whole morning.
options: ~You must be tired, but you haven't taken any break the whole morning.
~You must be tired, or you haven't taken any break the whole morning.
=You must be tired, for you haven't taken any break the whole morning.
~You must be tired, and you haven't taken any break the whole morning.
questions.examples:
I go to the park every Sunday, for I love to watch the ducks on the lake.
Most of the visitors were happy just sitting around in the shade, for it had been a long, dusty journey on the train.

Explanation:
The word FOR is most often used as a preposition, of course, but it does serve, on rare occasions, as a coordinating conjunction. Its function is to introduce the reason for the preceding clause.

note: Select the correct form of the sentence for the following questions, some of the sentences may be correct in their original form:
